origin: 1940s: respelling of the adjective exact + -o.

definitions.definition: a utility knife with a very sharp replaceable blade.
definitions.example: my T-square, my X-acto knife, my blue pencil

definitions.definition: Central African CFA franc(s).

origin: alteration of Shang-tu, the name of an ancient city in what is now the Inner Mongolia region of China, as portrayed in Coleridge's poem Kubla Khan (1816).

definitions.definition: an idealized place of great or idyllic magnificence and beauty.
definitions.example: three architects and a planner combine to create a Xanadu

definitions.definition: proprietary term for alprazolam.

origin: 1960s: from the modern Latin name of the bacterium Xanthomonas campestris + -an.

definitions.definition: a substance produced by bacterial fermentation or synthetically and used in foods as a gelling agent and thickener. It is a polysaccharide composed of glucose, mannose, and glucuronic acid.
a salt or ester of xanthic acid.

origin: late 19th century: from Greek xanthos ‘yellow’ + -ene.

definitions.definition: a yellowish crystalline compound, whose molecule contains two benzene rings joined by a methylene group and an oxygen atom, and whose derivatives include brilliant, often fluorescent, dyes such as fluorescein and rhodamines.

origin: early 19th century: xanthic from Greek xanthos ‘yellow’ + -ic.

definitions.definition: an organic acid containing the group —OCS2H, examples of which are typically reactive solids.

origin: early 19th century: from Greek xanthos ‘yellow’ + -ic.

definitions.definition: yellowish.

origin: mid 19th century: from xanthic + -ine4.

definitions.definition: a crystalline compound found in blood and urine which is an intermediate in the metabolic breakdown of nucleic acids to uric acid.

origin: mid 19th century: from Greek xanthos ‘yellow’ + -oma.

definitions.definition: an irregular yellow patch or nodule on the skin, caused by deposition of lipids.

origin: mid 19th century: from Greek xanthos ‘yellow’ + phullon ‘leaf’.

definitions.definition: a yellow or brown carotenoid plant pigment which causes the autumn colours of leaves.
the principal or horizontal axis of a system of coordinates, points along which have a value of zero for all other coordinates.

origin: early 21st century: short for Extensible Business Reporting Language .

definitions.definition: an XML-based markup language used for standardized reporting of business information, especially that relating to a company’s financial performance.
definitions.example: XBRL enhances the capabilities of regulators to validate financial data

definitions.definition: East Caribbean dollar(s).

the phenomenon in a female mammal whereby the genes in one of the pair of X chromosomes are silenced, with the result that their effects are equivalent to those in the male, with only a single X chromosome.
(in humans and other mammals) a sex chromosome, two of which are normally present in female cells (designated XX) and only one in male cells (designated XY).
ex dividend.

origin: mid 18th century: alteration (influenced by Spanish xabeque ) of French chebec, via Italian from Arabic šabbāk .

definitions.definition: a small three-masted Mediterranean sailing ship with lateen and square sails.

origin: modern Latin (plural), from xeno- ‘strange’ + Greek arthron ‘joint’ (because of the peculiar accessory articulations in the vertebrae).

definitions.definition: an order of mammals that comprises the edentates.

origin: 1990s: of unknown origin.

definitions.definition: a synthetic drug which blocks pancreatic enzymes involved in the digestion of fats, used to treat obesity.

origin: early 21st century: blend of x (as in Generation X) and millennial.

definitions.definition: a member of an age group born after Generation X and before the millennial generation (specifically in the late 1970s and early 1980s).
definitions.example: xennials grew up in a time where landline phones were used to organize catch-ups with friends

definitions.definition: relating to or denoting a substance, typically a synthetic chemical, that is foreign to the body or to an ecological system.
definitions.example: xenobiotic synthesis

definitions.definition: a xenobiotic substance.
a xenobiotic substance.

origin: late 19th century: from xeno- ‘foreign’ + crystal.

definitions.definition: a crystal in an igneous rock which is not derived from the original magma.

origin: 1990s: from xeno- + oestrogen.

definitions.definition: any natural or synthetic compound introduced into the body that mimics the effects of oestrogen or promotes its production.
fertilization of a flower by pollen from a flower on a genetically different plant.
relating to or involving tissues or cells belonging to individuals of different species.
a tissue graft or organ transplant from a donor of a different species from the recipient.
a piece of rock within an igneous mass which is not derived from the original magma but has been introduced from elsewhere, especially the surrounding country rock.

origin: 1950s: from Greek xenos ‘stranger, foreigner’, (adjective) ‘strange’.

definitions.definition: (chiefly in science fiction) the scientific study of alien biology, cultures, etc.

origin: late 19th century: from Greek, neuter of xenos ‘strange’.

definitions.definition: the chemical element of atomic number 54, a member of the noble gas series. It is obtained by distillation of liquid air, and is used in some specialized electric lamps.
a person having a dislike of or prejudice against people from other countries.
definitions.example: they say they are being unfairly typecast as xenophobes and racists

definitions.definition: dislike of or prejudice against people from other countries.
definitions.example: the resurgence of racism and xenophobia

definitions.definition: having or showing a dislike of or prejudice against people from other countries.
definitions.example: xenophobic attitudes

origin: from Greek xenos ‘stranger, foreigner’, (adjective) ‘strange’.

definitions.definition: relating to a foreigner or foreigners.
definitions.example: xenophobia

origin: late 19th century: modern Latin, from xeno- ‘strange’ + Greek pous ‘foot’.

definitions.definition: the African clawed frog, much used in embryological research and formerly in pregnancy testing, as it produces eggs in response to substances in the urine of a pregnant woman.

origin: mid 19th century: from xeno-, apparently erroneously for Greek kenos ‘vain, empty’, + timē ‘honour’ (because it was wrongly supposed to contain a new metal).

definitions.definition: a yellowish-brown mineral which occurs in some igneous rocks and consists of a phosphate of yttrium and other rare earth elements.
the process of grafting or transplanting organs or tissues between members of different species.
a tissue graft or organ transplant from a donor of a different species from the recipient.
definitions.example: ovarian tissue xenotransplants

definitions.definition: the chemical element xenon.

origin: late 19th century: from Greek, neuter of xenos ‘strange’.

definitions.definition: the chemical element of atomic number 54, a member of the noble gas series. It is obtained by distillation of liquid air, and is used in some specialized electric lamps.

origin: 1920s: from xero- ‘dry’ + -ic.

definitions.definition: (of an environment or habitat) containing little moisture; very dry.
definitions.example: xeric conditions

origin: 1980s: from xeric + -scape.

definitions.definition: a garden or landscape created in a style that requires little or no irrigation or other maintenance, used in arid regions.
definitions.example: it has become trendy to replace water-thirsty gardens with xeriscapes

definitions.definition: cultivate (an area) as a xeriscape.
definitions.example: I wanted to remove the grass along the sidewalk and xeriscape that area too

origin: 1980s: from xeric + -scape.

definitions.definition: cultivate (an area) as a xeriscape.
definitions.example: I wanted to remove the grass along the sidewalk and xeriscape that area too

origin: mid 19th century: modern Latin, from xero- ‘dry’ + Greek derma ‘skin’.

definitions.definition: any of various diseases characterized by extreme dryness of the skin, especially a mild form of ichthyosis.

origin: late 19th century: pigmentosum, neuter of Latin pigmentosus ‘pigmented’.

definitions.definition: a rare hereditary defect of the enzyme system that repairs DNA after damage from ultraviolet rays, resulting in extreme sensitivity to sunlight and a tendency to develop skin cancer.
a dry copying process in which black or coloured powder adheres to parts of a surface remaining electrically charged after being exposed to light from an image of the document to be copied.
(of a plant or animal) adapted to a very dry climate or habitat, or to conditions where moisture is scarce.

origin: from Greek xēros ‘dry’.

definitions.definition: dry.
definitions.example: xeroderma

definitions.definition: abnormal dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea of the eye, with inflammation and ridge formation, typically associated with vitamin A deficiency.
a plant which needs very little water.

origin: 1950s: an invented name, based on xerography.

definitions.definition: a xerographic copying process.
definitions.example: printing methods include acrylic printing and colour Xerox

definitions.definition: copy (a document) by the Xerox process.
definitions.example: I shall have the typescript xeroxed today

origin: 1950s: an invented name, based on xerography.

definitions.definition: copy (a document) by the Xerox process.
definitions.example: I shall have the typescript xeroxed today

definitions.definition: a noteworthy special talent or quality.
definitions.example: there are plenty of luxury cars around, but the S-Type has that special X factor

definitions.definition: a variable in a given situation that could have the most significant impact on the outcome.
definitions.example: the young vote may turn out to be the X factor

definitions.definition: the height of a lower-case x, considered characteristic of a given typeface or script.

origin: from the stem of Xhosa umXhosa (plural amaXhosa ).

definitions.definition: a member of a South African people traditionally living in the province of Eastern Cape. They form the second largest ethnic group in South Africa after the Zulus.
the Bantu language of the Xhosa, related to Zulu and spoken by over 7 million people. It is one of the official languages of South Africa.
definitions.example: young people recited verses in Xhosa

origin: from the stem of Xhosa umXhosa (plural amaXhosa ).

definitions.definition: a member of a South African people traditionally living in the province of Eastern Cape. They form the second largest ethnic group in South Africa after the Zulus.
the Bantu language of the Xhosa, related to Zulu and spoken by over 7 million people. It is one of the official languages of South Africa.
definitions.example: young people recited verses in Xhosa

definitions.definition: relating to the Xhosa or their language.
Extensible Hypertext Markup Language, a hybrid of HTML and XML.
a dialect of Chinese spoken by about 36 million people, mainly in Hunan province.

origin: mid 19th century: from Greek xiphos ‘sword’ + sternum.

definitions.definition: the lowest part of the sternum; the xiphoid process.

origin: mid 18th century: from Greek xiphoeidēs, from xiphos ‘sword’.

definitions.definition: sword-shaped.

origin: mid 18th century (as xiphoid cartilage ): xiphoid from Greek xiphoeidēs, from xiphos ‘sword’.

definitions.definition: the cartilaginous section at the lower end of the sternum, which is not attached to any ribs, and gradually ossifies during adult life.

origin: Greek.

definitions.definition: the fourteenth letter of the Greek alphabet ( Ξ, ξ ), transliterated as ‘x’.
irradiation with X-rays.

origin: mid 19th century: abbreviation.

definitions.definition: excellent.
definitions.example: an xlnt novel

definitions.definition: extra large (as a clothes size).

origin: X representing the initial chi of Greek Khristos ‘Christ’.

definitions.definition: another term for Christmas.

origin: 1990s: short for Extensible Markup Language .

definitions.definition: a metalanguage which allows users to define their own customized markup languages, especially in order to display documents on the internet.

origin: early 18th century: from Greek; related to xein ‘carve’.

definitions.definition: (in ancient Greece) a primitive wooden image of a deity.
West African CFA franc(s).
another term for exclusive OR.
CFP franc(s).
the twenty-fourth letter of the alphabet.
a shape like that of a letter X.
definitions.example: two wires in the form of an X

definitions.definition: a cross-shaped written symbol.
the Roman numeral for ten.
experience point or experience points.
definitions.example: you need to regain the XP spent on those skills

definitions.definition: pornographic or indecent.
definitions.example: there was some X-rated humour

definitions.definition: the branch of astronomy concerned with the detection and measurement of high-energy electromagnetic radiation emitted by celestial objects.
the study of crystals and their structure by means of the diffraction of X-rays by the regularly spaced atoms of crystalline materials.
a small almost transparent freshwater fish with an opaque body cavity. Native to South America, it is popular in aquaria.

origin: translation of German X-Strahlen (plural), from X- (because, when discovered in 1895, the nature of the rays was unknown) + Strahl ‘ray’.

definitions.definition: an electromagnetic wave of high energy and very short wavelength, which is able to pass through many materials opaque to light.

a photographic or digital image of the internal composition of something, especially a part of the body, produced by X-rays being passed through it and being absorbed to different degrees by different materials.
definitions.example: the fracture was clearly visible on the X-ray

definitions.definition: a code word representing the letter X, used in radio communication.
photograph or examine with X-rays.
definitions.example: luggage bound for the hold is X-rayed

origin: translation of German X-Strahlen (plural), from X- (because, when discovered in 1895, the nature of the rays was unknown) + Strahl ‘ray’.

definitions.definition: photograph or examine with X-rays.
definitions.example: luggage bound for the hold is X-rayed

definitions.definition: a device for generating X-rays by accelerating electrons to high energies and causing them to strike a metal target from which the X-rays are emitted.

origin: Vietnamese, from French sou .

definitions.definition: a monetary unit of Vietnam, equal to one hundredth of a dong.

origin: late 19th century: from Greek xulon ‘wood’ + the passive suffix -ēma .

definitions.definition: the vascular tissue in plants which conducts water and dissolved nutrients upwards from the root and also helps to form the woody element in the stem.

origin: mid 19th century: from xylo- ‘of wood’ + -ene.

definitions.definition: a volatile liquid hydrocarbon obtained by distilling wood, coal tar, or petroleum, used in fuels and solvents and in chemical synthesis.

origin: late 19th century: from xylose + -ite1 + -ol.

definitions.definition: a sweet-tasting crystalline alcohol derived from xylose, present in some plant tissues and used as an artificial sweetener in foods.
a woodcut or wood engraving, especially an early one.
the art of engraving on wood or of printing from woodblocks.
(especially of an insect larva or mollusc) feeding on or boring into wood.

origin: mid 19th century: from xylo- ‘of wood’ + -phone.

definitions.definition: a musical instrument played by striking a row of wooden bars of graduated length with one or more small wooden or plastic beaters.

origin: from Greek xulon ‘wood’.

definitions.definition: relating to wood.
definitions.example: xylophagous

definitions.definition: a sugar of the pentose class which occurs widely in plants, especially as a component of hemicelluloses.

origin: Latin, from Greek xustos ‘smooth’, from xuein ‘to scrape’.

definitions.definition: (in ancient Greece) a long portico used by athletes for exercise.
(in ancient Rome) a garden walk or terrace.
